front.title: New Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP) Block-Wise Transfer Options

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Only the deviation from Block1 and Block2 options will be specified.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
Readers should be familiar with the terms and concepts defined in .

section.title: The Block3 and Block4 Options
section.t: The properties of Block3 ad Block4 options are shown in Table 1. The formatting of this table follows the one used in Table 4 of (Section 5.10). The C, U, N, and R columns indicate the properties Critical, Unsafe, NoCacheKey, and Repeatable defined in Section 5.4 of . Since NoCacheKey only has a meaning for options that are Safe-to-Forward, the N column is filled with a dash for Block3 ad Block4 options.
The Block3 Option pertains to the request payload, and the Block4 Option pertains to the response payload.
The xxx option () is a critical option used to detect and prevent infinite loops of CoAP requests when proxies are involved.
Both Block3 and Block4 options are not repeatable. Therefore, any request carrying multiple Block3 (or Block4) options MUST be handled following the procedure specified in Section 5.4.5 of .
The structure of Block3 ad Block4 options MUST follow the structure defined in Secion 2.2 of .
The Block3 ad Block4 options are not safe to forward.

section.title: HTTP-Mapping Considerations
section.t: This section focuses on the HTTP mappings specific to the CoAP extension specified in this document. As a reminder, the basic normative requirements on HTTP/CoAP mappings are defined in Section 10 of . The implementation guidelines for HTTP/CoAP mappings are elaborated in .
The rules defined in Section 5 of are to be followed.
